docs.lead_paragraph: Signs of a Real Estate Slowdown Begin Appearing in Different Markets A real estate slowdown that began in a handful of cities this summer has spread to almost every hot housing market in the country, including New York. More sellers are putting their homes on the market, houses are selling less quickly and prices are no longer increasing as rapidly as they were in the spring, according to local data and interviews with brokers. In Manhattan, the average sales price fell almost 13 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter, according to a widely followed report to be released today by Miller Samuel, an appraisal firm, and Prudential Douglas Elliman, a real estate firm. [Page A1.] Home builders have never had it so good. Builders are reporting blistering earnings and their shares are trading at or near record highs. And many builders are beginning to cash in. [C1.] Energy Department Begins Campaign to Reduce Fuel Use The Energy Department announced a campaign to persuade Americans to use less energy, a response to record prices for natural gas and heating oil as cooler weather arrives. The energy secretary, Samuel W. Bodman, said that new supplies were still essential but that they were a long-term solution. To react to the damage from hurricanes Katrina and Rita, Mr. Bodman said, only conservation would offer any immediate help. [A21.] High-Speed Internet at 35,000 Feet, but Not in America Boeing's Connexion unit, which sells high-speed Internet access on the aircraft that Boeing builds, has sold its service to airlines in Europe, Asia and the Middle East but airlines in the United States, citing cost concerns, have not bought into it. [C1.] Security lines, weather delays and equipment failures make flying a burden for many. For Jason Green, it is a slice of heaven, virtually the only place he is not bombarded by phone calls and e-mail messages. But federal regulators are reassessing the rules barring phones in the air. [C1.] S.U.V. Sales Take a Big Drop in September Sales of large sport utility vehicles were down 43 percent in September, according to a new report, dealing a blow to General Motors and Ford Motor, which have been increasing their reliance on truck-based S.U.V.'s. Last month, G.M. saw its overall sales fall 24.2 percent and Ford's sales decline 20.3 percent. In contrast, sales at Toyota rose 10.3 percent, Honda increased 11.7 percent and Nissan 16.4 percent. [C1.] Only Thing Missing From Microsoft 's Xbox 360 Is Games In the five months since Microsoft unveiled the Xbox 360, the company has tried to generate excitement by staging demonstrations of the console's ability to play music and display digital photographs and by trumpeting its online community features. But something is missing: the games. [C1.] New Insurance Plan for Part-Time Workers Dozens of part-time workers at six large companies have begun to sign up for low-cost, limited health benefits in a national program for uninsured employees. [C2.] US Airways Repurchases Stake From a Federal Agency US Airways said it would pay $115.8 million to buy stock warrants that had given the federal government a sizeable stake in America West, which merged with US Airways last week. [C2.] Stocks Mixed Amid Concerns About Inflation Stocks were mixed after a report showed that the nation's manufacturing sector was expanding but costs were rising. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 33.22 points, to 10,535.48. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 2.11, at 1,226.70, and the Nasdaq gained 3.74, to 2,155.43. [C11.] A $3.3 Million Merger of Real Estate Companies Brandywine Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust based in suburban Philadelphia, said it had reached an agreement to acquire Prentiss Properties Trust of Dallas in a cash, stock and debt-assumption deal that the companies said was worth about $3.3 billion. Both companies specialize in the development, ownership and management primarily of office buildings. [C4.] Manufacturers Expanded Last Month, but Costs Climbed The nation's manufacturing sector shook off the impact of Hurricane Katrina and robustly expanded during September, but prices for raw materials surged, raising the prospect of higher inflation and interest rates. [C4.] Egg Producers Alter Labels Over Care Implications The label ''Animal Care Certified'' on egg cartons was supposed to assure egg buyers that hens were getting enough food, water and cage space to flap their wings. But after complaints by an animal welfare group that the labels were misleading consumers into thinking that hens were receiving indisputably humane care, the Federal Trade Commission approved a labeling change last week. Advertising [C18.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of part-time workers at six large companies have begun to sign up for low-cost, limited health benefits in a new national program for uninsured employees. The HR Policy Association, a nonprofit organization of senior personnel executives, said enrollment was under way at units of General Electric, I.B.M., Sears, Avon Products, the computer-storage company EMC and the auto supplier Federal-Mogul.

headline.main: Program Offers Health Care For Some Part-Time Workers

docs.abstract: Dozens of part-time workers at six large companies begin to sign up for low-cost, limited health benefits in new national program for uninsured employees; HR Policy Assn, nonprofit organization of senior personnel executives, says enrollment is under way at units of General Electric, Sears, IBM, Avon Products, computer-storage company EMC and auto supplier Federal-Mogul; six more large employers plan to start enrolling uninsured workers in next few weeks (M)
docs.snippet: Dozens of part-time workers at six large companies have begun to sign up for low-cost, limited health benefits in a new national program for uninsured employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal aid to victims of Hurricane Katrina is already faltering on two crucial fronts: health care and housing. Incompetence is part of the problem, but deeper political issues also play a crucial role. Start with health care, where conservative senators, generally believed to be acting on behalf of the White House, have blocked bipartisan legislation that would provide all low-income victims of Katrina with health coverage under Medicaid.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says federal aid to victims of Hurricane Katrina is already faltering on health care and housing fronts, with Bush administration opposing Medicaid entitlement for low-income victims and favoring creation of public housing in form of trailer parks rather than voucher program; says administration is trying to treat Katrina's victims as harshly as political realities allow, so as not to create precedent for other aid (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration is trying to treat Hurricane Katrina's victims as harshly as the political realities allow, so as not to create a precedent for other aid efforts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government contends that General Motors' pension fund is $31 billion short of what it owes its work force, according to closely held government data, a figure in stark contrast to G.M.'s assurances that its pension plans are ''fully funded.'' The government's finding of a huge imbalance suggests that the pension fund may have much larger claims on the company than G.M.'s financial filings have indicated. It was calculated by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the federal agency whose job it is to insure employee pensions if a company fails to meet its obligations.

headline.main: G.M. and a U.S. Agency See Pensions in Different Lights

docs.abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp contends that General Motors' pension fund is $31 billion short of what it owes its work force; GM insists that fund is fully funded; agency makes its estimate on what is called termination basis, measuring amount that GM would owe its workers if it were to terminate its pension plans immediately; GM's calculation that its pension plan is fully funded assumes that fund will keep going, rather than be ended; GM's estimate of its pensions on termination basis remains secret; agency does not suggest that GM is about to go bankrupt or that it needs $31 billion right away, because pensions are long-term obligations (M)
docs.snippet: The government contends that General Motors' pension fund is $31 billion short of what it owes its work force, according to closely held government data.

byline.original: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSHand DANNY HAKIM

docs.lead_paragraph: Florence Henderson. Fred and Ethel Mertz. They're not likely to knock Paris Hilton or Brad and Angelina off the cover of People. But pop culture figures of a certain age, or from a certain era, are playing lead roles in a vast new marketing and advertising blitz.

headline.main: To Promote a New Drug Benefit, Marketers Are Using Some Old Scripts

docs.abstract: Marketing campaigns for new Medicare prescription drug benefits face significant challenges, including target audience--older people--that does not typically attract marketers' time and money and the very complexity of benefit packages themselves; television campaigns are therefore emphasizing the friendly and familiar, including computer-altered clips of Fred and Ethel Mertz from I Love Lucy show (Pacificare), Florence Henderson (Cigna Senior Care) and Willard Scott (UnitedHealth Group); photos (M)
docs.snippet: Pop culture figures of a certain age, or from a certain era, are playing lead roles in a vast new marketing and advertising blitz.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephen scoffs at the idea of emulating Canada's health system, writing: "I suggest you read the editorial column in this week's Barron's,which addresses the enumerable shortcomings of the Canadian healthcare system that you so heartily applaud. If you believe that the United States, as well as the rest of the world, can provide universal, government-financed, quality health care,you are deluding yourself. We and the rest of the world,will no sooner be able to do that than we will be able to provide universally guaranteed, meaningful retirement benefits (social security) or universally paid, quality education. Until we explore alternative means of financing these so called rights and cost-effective, alternative ways to deliver these services, the only way to contain their costs will be rationing. Those that will suffer will be the ones you (and most of us) want to help the most. The answer in health care, as in retirement and education, is not in socializing the costs. "

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the night of this year's New York primary, and when a billionaire like Mayor Michael Bloomberg holds a party to celebrate his candidacy, it's no small affair. The spacious ballroom of the Marriott in downtown Brooklyn was overflowing with free beer and pigs-in-blankets, and a band revved up the throngs of supporters. ''We love Mike! We love Mike!'' they chanted. Among the supporters was Alex Martins, a goateed Indian lawyer in a business suit and a Hawaiian shirt. He was flanked by three fellow Indians in shirt-sleeves who looked a little lost. Martins waved a big blue Bloomberg poster enthusiastically and joined in the chant; his entourage stood around silently.

headline.main: So the Jains, They Have a Problem With BEEF in the School Lunches. Who They Gonna Call?

docs.snippet: Meet Alex Martins, from Queens by way of Mumbai, an old-fashioned fixer for New York's new immigrants.

docs.lead_paragraph: MARC LEFFLER was a successful oral surgeon in his mid-30's when he began to experience progressive weakness in his dominant hand, accompanied by wrist and hand pain. The condition worsened with time, and treatment was not effective. When Dr. Leffler realized that his ability to perform surgery would eventually be affected, he knew a career switch was inevitable. He slowly began to phase out his practice while he attended law school part time. Today, Dr. Leffler, now 48 and a resident of Pomona, N.Y., is a trial lawyer focusing on medical and dental malpractice and personal injury.

headline.main: Midcareer Disabilities Force Workers to Retool

docs.lead_paragraph: As residents of New Orleans begin to re-enter the homes and businesses left standing after Hurricane Katrina, many may face an obstacle more pervasive and possibly more dangerous than mud and rotting wood: mold spores reproducing inside tens of thousands of buildings. Public health experts say mold could present significant risks and may force thousands of demolitions.

headline.main: Blanket of Mold Threatens Health and Homes

docs.snippet: Many in New Orleans may face an obstacle more pervasive and possibly more dangerous than mud and rotting wood: mold spores reproducing inside buildings.

docs.lead_paragraph: A STATE law that was scheduled to take effect on Saturday requires health insurers to cover infertility treatments for women until they turn 40, making Connecticut the 15th state in the nation to adopt such a law, but the first to limit its scope by age. Both women and lawmakers who favored the law, including women who testified before the General Assembly's Public Health Committee, said the new legislation was just a start. Representative Donald Sherer, Republican of Stamford and New Canaan -- who, as a lawyer, specializes in reproductive law -- said last Tuesday that he planned to pursue changes in the next legislative session.

headline.main: Infertility Treatments Now Covered, to a Point
